concern:
A blurb on my situation and why I’m asking this: I’m currently in my school’s business program (includes majors in finance, economics, info sys, marketing, etc) with the aim of graduating with a bachelors in management information systems, however calculus has been a major roadblock for me.   
I barely passed precalculus at a cc the first time I took it, failed calculus at the cc, then had to retake precalculus due to credit issues when transferring but failed it this time, and now I’ll need to take calculus again at a cc, and I have little hope that I’ll pass. I have a deadline to pass that class this next semester and if I don’t I’ll be kicked from the business program and won’t have access to any of the above listed majors. Already the prospects of having a nice info sys job are starting to dim. The only major I can think of that will allow me to not take calculus and graduate in a reasonable time is interdisciplinary studies. My remaining classes until I graduate would be poli sci because why not, I think it’s an interesting subject and there’d be no point to taking my remaining business or finance or information systems classes if I can’t have that major at the end of it.  


..  


Tl;dr I suck at calculus  


So basically what my two questions are: will I be stuck working minimum wage jobs with the degree in the title or is there some hope for a “normal” working-in-an-office job?  
What are some jobs that are open to both business and political science majors (because I’m assuming that’s where I’d most likely be heading with this plan)?

dialogue_total.statement: Hello! I'm glad you're here today. Whenever you're ready, feel free to share what's on your mind or any concerns you might have.
Hey, thanks for seeing me. I'm just really worried about my future, especially with my major and this whole calculus thing. It's been stressing me out and I don't know what to do.
That sounds really challenging, feeling stressed about your major and calculus. Can you tell me more about what's been going on with calculus and how it's affecting you?

client: Yeah, calculus has been a nightmare for me. I've failed it once, and now I have to pass it next semester, or I'll be out of my program. It's just overwhelming to think I'll lose out on my major because of one class.
It seems like calculus is really important to your future and your major. How do you envision things changing for you if you successfully pass this class?

Honestly, if I somehow manage to pass, it would be a huge relief. It would mean I could stay in my program and keep working toward the info sys degree I really want. But right now, it's hard to even think about success when I'm so worried about failing again.

It sounds like passing calculus would open up a lot of opportunities for you and align with your goal of getting that information systems degree. What would it mean for you personally to achieve this success, and how might it impact other areas of your life?

I think it would definitely boost my confidence and make me feel less stuck, you know? Plus, it might ease up some of the stress and anxiety I've been feeling, which could help me focus better on other parts of my life too.

Passing calculus seems to hold real significance for your confidence and overall well-being, which in turn could positively impact other areas of your life. Based on what you've shared, possible next steps might include seeking tutoring support or creating a structured study plan. What do you think could be your first step in moving toward passing calculus?

I think looking into tutoring might be a good first step, but I'm a bit unsure of how to find the right resources or if it would actually help. Creating a study plan sounds useful too, but I feel like I need guidance on how to structure it effectively.

Therapist: It sounds like you're open to exploring both tutoring and structuring a study plan. Based on what you said, possible options include researching tutoring services at your school or seeking online platforms, and perhaps meeting with an advisor to help structure an effective study plan. What do you feel would be most helpful for you to focus on first?
client: I think starting with finding a tutor might be the most immediate help, especially since I struggle with the material. Maybe I can ask around on campus or look online to see what’s available.

Therapist: It sounds like you're considering asking around on campus or exploring online options for a tutor as your first step, which shows you're taking proactive steps. How do you see yourself beginning this process, and what might be some challenges you anticipate in finding the right tutor?

client: I guess I could start by checking out the resources at the student services or maybe even ask my professors if they know of anyone who tutors. A challenge might be finding someone who’s a good fit both in terms of teaching style and availability, plus making sure I can afford it.

That sounds like a thoughtful approach, checking with student services and professors could lead you to some reliable tutoring options. It's great to see you taking proactive steps towards finding the right support. Balancing teaching style, availability, and affordability can indeed be challenging, but it's encouraging to see you considering these factors. Remember, taking it one step at a time can make the process feel more manageable. Perhaps beginning with student services could offer some guidance or even financial options. You're showing a lot of determination, and that's something to be proud of. Let's touch base next time on how things are progressing, and feel free to reach out if you need to explore more strategies or need some encouragement along the way.
Thanks, I appreciate that. I'll start with student services and see where that leads. Definitely hoping it all works out, but a little nervous about it too.

It's completely understandable to feel a bit nervous, but your plan to begin with student services is a strong step forward. You've shown a lot of courage by acknowledging the challenges and being proactive about seeking support. Remember, it's okay to take things one day at a time, and leaning on the resources available can really help lighten the load. As you move forward, remember you’ve got this, and I’m here to support you. Keep going, and let’s catch up soon to see how things are unfolding. I'm confident you're on the right path.
Thanks for the encouragement. I'll definitely keep you posted on how it goes.

I'm glad to hear that. You've already taken the first step by deciding to reach out to student services, and that's a significant move. Remember, each small step you take is bringing you closer to your goal of passing calculus and feeling more secure in your program. You've got a good plan in place, and I'm here to support you as you navigate through it. Keep me updated on your progress, and remember to be kind to yourself through this process. You're doing great, and I'm confident that with your determination, you'll find the resources you need. Take care, and we'll talk again soon.
Sure thing, I’ll keep you updated. Hoping I can get through this okay.
